question: Which process is an important part of star formation?

content.source_1: In stellar astrophysics, an object is considered a star only after it achieves sustained hydrogen fusion in its core; absent fusion, it remains a protostar or brown dwarf.
content.source_2: Many treatments of star formation mark the completion of formation at the moment core hydrogen fusion ignites, because fusion-driven pressure halts further gravitational collapse.
content.source_3: Nuclear fusion provides the energy and pressure that establish hydrostatic equilibrium, the stable state characteristic of a newly formed star.
content.source_4: During the protostellar stage, luminosity comes mainly from gravitational contraction and accretion; sustained hydrogen fusion has not yet started.
content.source_5: The hallmark processes of star formation are molecular cloud fragmentation, gravitational collapse, disk-mediated accretion, and jets/outflowsâ€”processes that precede the onset of hydrogen burning.
content.source_6: Some objects produced by these same collapse and accretion mechanisms never ignite hydrogen fusion (becoming brown dwarfs), demonstrating that the formation mechanisms themselves do not require fusion.
